awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Quantifying diffusion and dynamics on healthcare, innovation and communication networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Many modern data collections, gathered for the purpose of providing insights into matters of national interest such as medical and technological innovation, typically measure quickly evolving interactions, in addition to traditional unit-level measurements, in the context of a network. This project develops an integrated research and educational program to enable scientific and quantitative analyses of interactions and other combinatorial measurements as they change over time. Technical problems being addressed include, but are not limited to: an efficient representation that facilitates quantitative analyses of large-scale networks; models of how information and behavior evolve over time as a consequence of the network context they are embedded in; and fast algorithms to perform estimation of critical parameters in these models. These methods will be demonstrated on case studies exploring: the diffusion of medical innovations among physicians and its impact on health; technological innovation dynamics in the United States and the role of non-compete agreements; the estimation of point-to-point communications on a network, from aggregate traffic that is passively monitored.

The presence of interactions and other combinatorial measurements as a source of observed variation in the data creates new statistical and inferential challenges. For instance, generalized linear model theory needs to be extended to responses on a network. The analysis of processes on a network often induces constraints that make the inferential problems ill posed, since they involve a large number of unknown quantities to describe few observations. Estimation may require sampling from, and integrating over, extremely constrained parameter spaces. Importantly, interactions do not necessarily encode statistical dependence. In this sense, dealing with observed interactions requires original thinking; the data settings they entail are not amenable to analysis with classical methods, in which interactions are inferred as a means to encode dependence among unit-level observations. This project tackles technical challenges with a statistical and machine learning approach. Anticipated technical results include, but are not limited to: (1) a new wavelet decomposition of multivariate and dynamic networks; (2) statistical models of diffusion of information on a given network, and models of inhomogeneous network dynamics in continuous time; (3) scalable estimation algorithms for these models; and (4) theoretical foundations of inference with big data. This research will be evaluated qualitatively and quantitatively, at Harvard and in collaboration with industrial partners.

The proposed research is integrated with an interdisciplinary educational program, which will attract undergraduates to research at the intersection of statistics and computer science, in the context of problems of national importance. It will provide opportunities to actively encourage students from underrepresented groups to pursue careers in statistics and computer science. Key elements of the educational program include the development of a statistical machine learning curriculum; lectures on YouTube available to everyone; tutorials at national and international conferences and workshops; and a monograph. Outreach activities include open-source software and webtools for the community at-large, and a collaborative effort with industrial partners to leverage the new computational tools and algorithms for benefiting their pools of users worldwide. Additional details regarding the project can be found at: http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~airoldi/career.html.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new methods and algorithms for analyzing diffusion and dynamics on social and communication networks with rich node information. Deliverables included new tools to perform wavelet-like decomposition of large networks; to estimate the effects of individuals' attributes on the potential for diffusion of disease and behavior in a network; to quantify the effects of behavior dynamics and technical skills on creativity and innovation; to infer social influence potentials on a network; and to characterize modes of interaction between processes on a network and network dynamics.

 

This project had technical innovations, which included: (1) the establishment of a new graph wavelet decomposition for multivariate and dynamic networks; (2) the development of probabilistic models of diffusion of information on a given network, and models of inhomogeneous network dynamics in continuous time; (3) the design of scalable estimation algorithms, linear and sub-linear in the number of edges; and (4) the development of theoretical foundations of inference with big data. These research directions provided new theory, methods and algorithms to address complementary aspects of two open problems of current interest: semi-parametric decomposition of large, attributed networks and analysis of diffusion processes on a network, inhomogeneous network dynamics, and the feedback effects of processes on network dynamics.

 

This project has advanced technical ideas and scalable computational methods that extend the toolbox at the disposal of analysts who carry out analyses of complex network data, specifically with:

  • A new graph wavelet decomposition for multivariate and dynamic networks
  • Probabilistic models of diffusion of information on a given network and models of inhomogeneous network dynamics in continuous time
  • Scalable estimation algorithms with linear and sublinear in the number of edges

 

Additionally, this project developed a theoretical basis for scalable inference algorithms, such as stochastic approximations.

 

The methods we developed for this project aimed to benefit the work of scientists who analyze network experiments and or carry out network data analyses.  As part of a collaboration with Yale University, the PI has used network tools to analyze social networks data in Honduras. A first major publication on the analysis of negative social ties was published in 2019.

 

This project also advanced work on graphlets, with the further development of the graphlet decomposition of a weighted network. This work encodes a notion of social information based on social structure. Additionally, as part of this project, we developed asymptotic theory for the original graphlet methodology, and also extended the graphlet model and inference algorithm to deal with dynamic networks. We also explored the theoretical properties of the graphlet decomposition, including computational complexity, redundancy and expected accuracy and developed two substantial graphlet analyses of messaging patterns on Facebook and of criminal network associations in the 19th century.

 

Further, this project developed theory that shows under what conditions a graphlet network decomposition leads to a consistent estimation of all the parameters involved. The PI completed the work on methods to analyze traffic dynamics on communication networks. This research is summarized in the published paper by Airoldi & Blocker (JASA 2013).

This project also further developed novel stochastic approximation strategies for inference with large data sets. In this area, the PI and his students pioneered a class of procedures referred to as implicit stochastic approximations, or implicit stochastic gradient descent procedures (when a gradient is available), which can be seen as a stochastic variant of proximal methods, or as an extension of the classical Robbins & Monro (1951) stochastic approximation procedure, in which the iterates are defined through implicit equations. Briefly, in a 2014 ICML paper, we analyzed frequentist properties of the estimators implied by SGD procedures, implicit or not. This is an original piece of analysis in an area where the only convergence ever considered is that of the approximation to the truth, for a given data set.

 

In a follow-up paper published on Statistics and Computing, we reviewed the literature on stochastic approximations and offered some insights. The insights explain the empirical observations about stability of the implicit procedures; formulas that detail the loss of information of SGD procedures with respect to the MLE, in general, and illustrative examples that suggest  how SGD estimators end up weighting data points unevenly thus incurring in a loss of efficiency; an example in which a reparameterization prevents loss of efficiency in an SGD estimator, something that was not thought possible to accomplish due to the nature of the approximation.  In a major paper with the Annals of Statistics, we developed a general theory of implicit SGD procedure, including normality of the implied estimators, non-asymptotic bound, applications beyond GLMs to Mestimators and Cox proportional hazard models, extensions of the analysis to AdaGrad and other popular SGD inspired procedures, and a vast array of empirical comparisons with state-of-the-art estimation procedures for large data sets.
